channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus in US: Live Updates
item.description: The first known death from the illness came in early February. An order by Trump will impose a 60-day halt in issuing green cards. Some stability returned to the energy market.

item.title: Santa Clara County Coronavirus Death Is First Known in U.S.
item.description: The earliest U.S. deaths publicly attributed to the virus had been on Feb. 26, when two people died in the Seattle area. Santa Clara County said an autopsy showed a Feb. 6 death was also related.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Scott Strazzante/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The earliest publicly known coronavirus death in the United States came in the Bay Area in early February, health officials said Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Is Making School Harder for Immigrant Students
item.description: The parents of millions of American schoolchildren are not fluent in English, presenting an extra challenge to learning at home.
item.dc:creator: Rikha Sharma Rani
item.media:description: A closed school in Kentfield, Calif., earlier this month.

item.title: Solving the Mysteries of Coronavirus With Genetic Fingerprints
item.description: Scientists traced the virus brought to the Seattle area in January. They were astonished to learn that the same branch of the virus traveled on through at least a dozen states and to other parts of the world.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker and Sheri Fink
item.media:credit: Miles Fortune for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man suspected of bringing the coronavirus from China to the United States landed at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, shown here in February.

item.title: Al Gore Endorses Joe Biden for President: ‘This Is Not Complicated’
item.description: The climate activist and former vice president announced his support on Earth Day and said, “If you want to start solving the climate crisis, this is not rocket science.”
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Courtney Pedroza/The Tennessean, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Al Gore in Nashville in November.

item.title: Orlando Moncada, a Building Foreman in Manhattan, Dies at 56
item.description: Mr. Moncada, who died of the coronavirus, left Peru 40 years ago in pursuit of the American dream. He then grabbed it with both hands.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:description: Orlando Moncada came to the United States from Peru and started as a porter. He ended up a foreman.

item.title: Bennie G. Adkins, 86, Dies; Honored for Vietnam Heroics
item.description: He was awarded the Medal of Honor in 2014 for bravery in battle and aided veterans in his later years. He died of the new coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.category: United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
item.media:description: President Barack Obama awarded the Medal of Honor to Bennie G. Adkins in a White House ceremony in 2014. He devoted his later years to helping Special Forces personnel readjust to civilian life.

item.title: ‘Pure Hell for Victims’ as Stimulus Programs Draw a Flood of Scammers
item.description: Trillions of dollars in stimulus funds have created a rush among criminals to take the money from those who need it the most.
item.dc:creator: Nathaniel Popper
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It is a little relief, and then you find out it isn’t happening,” said Krystle Phelps, 33, who discovered that a scammer had recently claimed her family’s $3,400 stimulus check.

item.title: U.S. Spy Agencies Weigh Tying Intelligence Sharing to Ending Bans on Gays
item.description: The move is part of an effort by the acting director of national intelligence to prod countries that outlaw homosexuality to instead decriminalize it.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Bernd von Jutrczenka/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The intelligence community should be pushing American values with the countries it does business with, Richard Grenell, the acting director of national intelligence, said in an interview this week.

item.title: The Virus Won’t Revive F.D.R.’s Arts Jobs Program. Here’s Why.
item.description: The Federal Art Project, part of Roosevelt’s sweeping employment plan, gave work to thousands of artists, but politics and society were different then.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Federal Art Project/WPA, via Smithsonian Archive of America Art
item.media:description: Sculptors at work in New York under the auspices of the Works Progress Administration’s Federal Art Project. The program produced more than 18,800 pieces of sculpture.

item.title: PG&E Chief Executive to Retire in June
item.description: Bill Johnson joined the troubled utility last year and will leave when the company resolves its bankruptcy case.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis
item.media:description: Bill Johnson joined Pacific Gas & Electric, the troubled California utility, last May and plans to retire in June.

item.title: All of the Ways You Can Help
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has left many in need, but there are many ways you can assist, and often no money is needed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Jake Mincy helps organize and pack boxes of food donations for distribution at the Covenant Mercy Mission food pantry operating out of Manor Community Church in Manhattan.

item.title: Coronavirus, Oil, Earth Day: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: 7 Travel Stories to Help You Celebrate the 50th Anniversary of Earth Day
item.description: Confined to the great indoors on Earth Day? These stories will help remind you of the natural world’s many splendors — and why environmental protections are of crucial importance for the future of the planet.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: An aerial view of the shore line of Kadavu Island in Fiji.

item.title: The Juggle of Working Motherhood, Trapped at Home
item.description: As families adjust to this new reality, it’s often mom’s Zoom meeting that has to wait.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina and Lisa Lerer

item.title: Chinese Agents Helped Spread Messages That Sowed Virus Panic in U.S., Officials Say
item.description: American officials were alarmed by fake text messages and social media posts that said President Trump was locking down the country. Experts see a convergence with Russian tactics.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Matthew Rosenberg and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A large screen in Beijing showing President Xi Jinping of China during his visit last month to the city of Wuhan.

item.title: Jay Inslee Endorses Biden, Citing Private Conversations on Climate Policy
item.description: The governor of Washington State, one of the Democratic Party’s most prominent environmentalists, urged progressives to get on board with the presumptive presidential nominee’s campaign.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns
item.media:description: Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington at a coronavirus briefing in Olympia this month. He said in an interview that he was confident Joseph R. Biden Jr. was “willing to aim faster and higher” on climate policy.

item.title: Stocks Rise as Oil Prices Rebound: Live Market Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Sycamore Partners had been planning to buy 55 percent of Victoria’s Secret.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Pandemic News
item.description: The European Union accused Poland and Hungary of undermining democracy — and awarded them billions. Meanwhile, shutdowns and an oil glut are crushing national economies.
item.media:description: An oil field north of Basra, Iraq, last month. Iraq will be harder hit than almost any other oil-dependent state, according to the International Energy Agency.

item.title: Trump Says Harvard Must Pay Back Relief Money He Signed Into Law
item.description: Joining a chorus of critics, the president appeared not to realize that Harvard had received $8.6 million in stimulus funding as part of a federal aid package to universities.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although coronavirus stimulus funds were allocated to colleges, critics were upset to see any federal money flow to Harvard, whose endowment was $40.9 billion in June.

item.title: Virginia Savage McAlester, ‘Queen of Dallas Preservation,’ Dies at 76
item.description: Her book “A Field Guide to American Houses,” published in 1984 and revised in 2013, made her a household name among preservationists and architecture buffs.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.category: A Field Guide to American Houses: The Definitive Guide to Identifying and Understanding America's Domestic Architecture (Book)
item.media:credit: Laure Joliet for The New York Times
item.media:description: Virginia Savage McAlester, an architectural historian and preservationist, in her Dallas sitting room in 2013. “There was tremendous backbone to her,” said one architecture critic.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: As some states ease restrictions, they are meeting resistance from mayors, health experts and business leaders who say it’s too soon.
item.dc:creator: Patrick J. Lyons

item.title: These Are the Most Challenged Books, According to the A.L.A.
item.description: Eight of the 10 titles identified in the American Library Association’s annual ranking of the most frequently banned or protested books featured L.G.B.T.Q. subject matter.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.media:description: The HBO host John Oliver with a copy of “A Day in the Life of Marlon Bundo,” which imagines a gay romance involving Vice President Mike Pence’s rabbit.

item.title: Trump Blocks Green Cards During Coronavirus
item.description: After pledging on Twitter to end immigration during the pandemic, President Trump moved to block new green cards but stopped short of ending all work visas.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Caitlin Dickerson
item.media:description: People waiting to reschedule their immigration hearings on Tuesday in Ciudad Juárez on an international bridge between the United States and Mexico.

item.title: The Census Needs to Count Women. The Pandemic Makes That Harder.
item.description: After noticing a gender gap in intention to participate, the Census Bureau kicked off a campaign this year to encourage more women to take part.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg

item.title: ‘I Am Beyond Disturbed’: Internal Dissent as States Reopen Despite Virus
item.description: Several mayors and employers have asked residents to ignore the Georgia governor’s declaration that some businesses can resume operation while the coronavirus lingers.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Robert Willett/The News & Observer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters on Tuesday called on Gov. Roy Cooper of North Carolina to follow other Southern states by reopening.

item.title: Trump’s 60-Day Ban of Green Cards Leaves Families Reeling
item.description: President Trump’s move to suspend some green cards could make it harder for many immigrants to reunite with loved ones or work in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Dickerson and Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: Twinkle Anand Pullat, right, and Sushita Surendran, seen here in a family photo. They work in Olive Branch, Miss., where they have bought a home and had a son, Vivaan.

item.title: Coronavirus Takes Over Political Advertising
item.description: Political campaigns were reluctant to focus too heavily on the coronavirus outbreak. What changed?
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Trump and Cuomo Put Aside Disputes During White House Meeting
item.description: After alternating praise and quarrels for weeks, President Trump and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York had what the governor called “a good conversation” over testing and aid to states and localities.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Jesse McKinley
item.media:description: President Trump on Tuesday during the daily coronavirus briefing at the White House.

item.title: New U.S. Treatment Guidelines for Covid-19 Don’t See Much Progress
item.description: A panel of experts said there was insufficient evidence about many drugs that have been considered as possible remedies for coronavirus patients, including some President Trump has advocated.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: The panel specifically advised against the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine, which was associated with an increased risk of death.

item.title: House Readies Historic Changes to Allow Remote Voting During Pandemic
item.description: Democratic leaders plan to temporarily dispatch with two centuries of precedent as the coronavirus upends American life and government.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:description: An empty hallway leading to the House chamber in the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Threatens Press Freedom Around the World, Report Says
item.description: The United States, which ranked 45th out of 180 countries and territories, and Brazil were becoming models of hostility toward the news media, according to the World Press Freedom Index.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: The New York Times, via Reporters Without Borders

item.title: ‘I’m Just Living a Nightmare’: Oil Industry Braces for Devastation
item.description: Across the United States, companies are laying off workers, shutting down wells and preparing for a prolonged slump as oil prices tumble.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss

item.title: The Quiet Hand of Conservative Groups in the Anti-Lockdown Protests
item.description: Groups in a loose coalition have tapped their networks to drive up turnout at recent rallies in state capitals and financed lawsuits, polling and research to combat the stay-at-home orders.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel, Jim Rutenberg and Lisa Lerer
item.media:description: People protested at the Washington State Capitol in Olympia on Sunday. Organizers see the events as unifying social and fiscal conservatives as well as civil libertarians.

item.title: Coronavirus Infections May Not Be Uncommon, Tests Suggest
item.description: Two preliminary efforts to survey citizens for antibodies to the virus have produced controversial results.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: A health care worker took a blood sample for an antibody test in Bolinas, Calif., on Monday. Elsewhere in the state, testing in two counties suggested that 2 percent to 4 percent of residents may have been infected.

item.title: What’s Next for Restaurants Shut Out of Paycheck Protection Program
item.description: Owners of many small, independent restaurants were passed over by a federal loan program. Now they fear that a new round may not solve their problems.
item.dc:creator: Pete Wells
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Renato Poliafito, who owns a small Brooklyn bakery and cafe, says he was denied a federal small-business loan because the fund had run dry.

item.title: Dan Scavino Promoted as Meadows Shuffles White House Communications Team
item.description: Mr. Scavino, who is said to be the only White House aide with access to the president’s personal Twitter account, will now be deputy chief of staff for communications.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dan Scavino, one of the original aides in President Trump’s 2016 campaign, has been the White House director of social media.
